Key Arguments: Government regulation of speech often benefits itself and its allies, potentially eroding freedoms.
The legislation is not applied equally, exempting political parties and professional news from its scope.
The media landscape in Australia is highly concentrated, which could lead to biased enforcement.
The regulation may deter smaller platforms due to administrative burdens and potential fines.
Determining what constitutes misinformation is subjective and influenced by biases.
Notable Quotes: This legislation will likely have far-reaching unforeseen consequences for political speech.
It seems unfair that such organisations may publish misinformation on digital platforms whilst others may not.
The likely result will be that it will be simpler and easier to simply not publish information to the Australian public rather than face punitive penalties.
Governments and the powerful understand that narrative control is real power.
